column4: it probably has more to do with the setup of the monitor than setup of the video-card. what driver does xorg use?
all info about what drivers your xorg uses are in /etc/X11/xorg.conf
what is the brand of your monitor?
what brand is your monitor?
hang on
here are all your specs for your monitor. write them up: http://www.monitorworld.com/Monitors/philips/107s.html
pay special care for HFreq/VFreq
your hfreq is 30-66 and vfreq is 50-130. This is the key to get your supported resolutions
run "sudo xorgcfg" and click on the monitor -> Configure monitor(s)
run "sudo xorgcfg" and click on the monitor -> Configure monitor(s)
did you start xorgcfg?
then click on the monitor in the top-right corner and choose "Configure monitor(s)"
in this window you manually type in "30 - 66" in Horizontal sync
type in "50 - 130" in Vertical sync
and then quit
after that log out of X and press CTRL+ALT+BACKSPACE. This will restart X with the new values
hmmm...
might be if you haven't set up the video-card... ouch.
maybe you should restart xorgcfg just to make sure the monitor is connected to the video card and that the monitor has got a name
if you have a look at "configure monitor(s)" again. At the bottom you will see "Select card connected to monitor" and there you should see probably "i810"? it should not say "none"
at least we now know that we have the basics set up. you can exit xorgcfg now
i found what's wrong. if you look at Section "Monitor" you will see that the info you wrote in xorgcfg is there but there's a # before the values. Remove them and save the file
happy it worked out for you :-)
have to go now. take care and have fun in the world of 1280x1024!!
